newsitem.title: POLAND: Warsaw bourse seen capped by primary mkt next week.
newsitem.headline: Warsaw bourse seen capped by primary mkt next week.

text.p: The Warsaw bourse edged up this week but analysts saw next week's large primary offers drawing capital away from the bourse and capping its upside potential.
Analysts said most stocks, trading now at 15.3 times historical earnings on average, looked fairly valued and were unlikely to spur significant growth or suffer sharp falls.
"It's a lot of money (the primary market offers) and there are no reasons for the bourse to move sharper and a sideways drift is most likely," said Marcin Billewicz of ING Barings. @
On Monday an initial public offer of metals trader Impexmetal SA worth at least 222 million zlotys opens and Kredyt Bank starts its 83-million zloty offering.

Poland's largest paper firm Celuloza Swiecie, which ends its 112.5 million zloty public subscription on Friday will have its shares allotted at a special bourse session on Tuesday and will start regular bourse trade on Friday.
The main WIG index rose 0.7 percent this week to 16,376.9 points on Friday. @

Analysts said this week's better-than-expected inflation figure showing year-on-year consumer price growth down to 16.6 percent could only have a longer-term impact as no interest rate movements were expected until the second half of the year.
Some analysts said the bourse was likely to experience a wave of growth possibly starting late April, before stabilising or even falling ahead of parliamentary elections in September.

Debt-ridden construction firm Espebepe was this week's top gainer, jumping 37.8 percent on hopes that the firm would convince its creditors to accept a new restructuring plan at a May 16 creditors' meeting. @
The week's biggest main market loser was Exbud, which fell 8.1 percent.
Gauge maker Apator SA will start trade on the parallel market on Thursday and Jutrzenka will have its shares transferred to the main market from the parallel market on Wednesday.
